Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2012 09:50AM DC197 wrote: Abby, It seems so unfair that you have to deal with this at such a young age.  Everyone usually thinks that cancer will strike the other gal (or guy) ... not me!  But, unfortunately sometimes it is "me" and we don't understand the reason for it.  But, trust me, you will be a better person for this "gift" of cancer.  It will be a struggle for a while, but God knows you are strong enough to handle it.  I hope you are reading this in the way I intended it ... that you will find the courage to fight this and be there for your son, and hopefully someday grandchildren.  And you will also be the person who comes back to these boards to encourage others.  You can do this ... and we are here to help. (((Hugs))) Diane
Posts.Title: I am so scared Abby20 kathleen1966

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2012 01:34AM DC197 wrote: Abby, I noticed that you asked for prayers, so I assume you are a person of faith.  Here is a little prayer that I say every day and it has given me strength when I feel so alone. "Lord, help me to remember that nothing will happen to me today that You and I together can't handle".   God bless! (((Hugs))) Diane
Posts.Title: I am so scared Abby20 kathleen1966

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2013 11:37PM DC197 wrote: I would have to agree with Moiralf.  The worrying about it would drive me crazy. No doctor, no matter how experienced, can be absolutely sure that what he feels is nothing to worry about.  Only a biopsy will tell you positively if it's a cyst or a tumor, and whether it's malignant or benign. It's your life, so if you want to find out, I'd advise you to push for a biopsy.  Either way, you will catch an early cancer or put your mind at rest that it's nothing. Best of luck to you Diane

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2013 12:20AM DC197 wrote: Hi Survivor, I don't mean to offend you in any way, but the last few lines of your story were upsetting to me.  I had thought that your problem was that you were unable to eat and keep food down.  But, as I was reading, it seemed that you were proud of losing the weight and becoming a size 14 and maybe had a fear that if you ate you would become that overweight person that you had been.  If I am mistaken, please forgive me, but if this somehow rings a bell with you, please discuss it with your doctor.  You are dealing with a lot right now, and I'm sure you realize that nutrition is very important, so do your best to stay healthy.  Wishing you the best... (((hugs))) Diane

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2012 10:35PM DC197 wrote: To kishana, Sometimes the wait is due to the slow processing by the insurance company who have to ok it before the test can be done.  I know it irritating ... our lives are at the mercy of insurance companies! (((Hugs))) Diane
Posts.Title: Got a problem...how long can I wait? autism_mom Paintingmywaythru

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2012 03:33PM - edited Sep 5, 2012 03:34PM by DC197 J45 - You are not a baby ... you are a strong woman who will cope with whatever comes your way!  This is the absolute worse time for you, the waiting for a diagnosis.  And, look at you, you are living and breathing and putting one foot in front of the other.  That's all any of us do when we're confronted by something that terrifies us.  We are no stronger than you are, so you will see the light at the end of the tunnel (and no, I do not mean THAT light). We are all here to hold your hand and help you through this.  Lymph nodes swell for many reasons - to "catch" the bad stuff is one reason, so even if it has gotten into the nodes (and you don't even know yet whether there ARE cancer cells), the lymph nodes may have prevented them from going any further. So don't borrow trouble.  I wish for you a good night's sleep ... give your troubles to God, He'll be up all night anyway!  Let us know how the procedure goes tomorrow, and we'll wait with you for hopefully good results. (((Hugs))) Diane
Posts.Title: on verge of diagnosis J45 Mindyandgang

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2012 06:23AM DC197 wrote: Hi Jill, I'm so sorry that you are in the club that nobody wants to join.  The good things are that you caught it early, it seems to be small, and it is ER/PR positive.  You didn't mention your age or if you have gone through menopause, but if you have, that's actually good, too.  I was on HRT for many years, too, but now I'm on hormone therapy to reduce the estrogen even further.  The next step is to see a breast surgeon and schedule your surgery. If you're having a lumpectomy, it's fairly easy and you should be home the same day. The surgeon will explain the sentinal node biopsy that he will perform during surgery to check the lymph nodes.  If the cancer hasn't spread to the lymph nodes, he will not take any more.  I suggest you take someone with you for your appointment with the BS.  Four ears are always better than two when listening for all the facts.  You can also bring a note pad to jot down your questions and his answers.  Come back here with updates and any questions that we can answer for you. (((hugs))) Diane
Posts.Title: New and scared jabal DC197

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2012 08:42PM DC197 wrote: Hi Jill, I'm glad to hear that you talked to your doctor and have gotten things in motion.  It really does get easier once you have a plan.  The anxiety should subside somewhat.  I was on HRT after a hysterectomy because at that time the doctors thought it was a good thing. They had said it prevented osteoporosis and was good for the heart.  Studies later showed that long-term use was not good, so I gradually lowered my doseage, but still on it until the bc was discovered.  I did have some aches and pains, but not unmanageable.  But the hot flashes -- they were unbearable, constant and waking up during the night, tearing my clothes off.  I took vitamin E for a while, and it helped a little, but I bought myself a couple of battery-powered fans and actually put one in bed with me at night.  Gradually, the frequency diminished, although I still get them occasionally. I had radiation and it was not horrible for me.  I did develop a red burn towards the end, but the nurses gave me some cooling gel dressings and it got better within a week or so.  It's an individual decision, so you can weigh the pros and cons, but be sure you get all the information from reliable sources - not an 86 yr old.  I'll be thinking of you Tuesday and saying a prayer that everything goes smoothly. (((hugs))) Diane
Posts.Title: New and scared jabal DC197

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2012 08:28AM DC197 wrote: Hi jabal, I'm so sorry you find the need to be in this forum, however I'm glad that you found it because it's the right place to be to ask questions and find support.  We all know how you feel.  Take some slow, deep breaths to calm yourself.  Radiologists are indeed experienced in what they are looking at, however, no one .. and I repeat, no one can absolutely tell you that it is cancer without a biopsy, and 80% of biopsies are benign.  Many doctors have been surprised by pathology reports when they had been certain of their diagnosis.  Whether your biopsy turns out to be B9 (which I am hoping to be the case) or malignant, please come back to the boards and let us know. We care. (((hugs))) Diane

Posts.Title: Thoughts, Comments, and Questions Welcomed! KD2011

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2012 12:30PM DC197 wrote: Hi Wheatwoman,  Welcome to the place where no one wants to be, but happy that you have found us.  I cannot advise you on what to do, but only give you my personal opinion.  There is no way that I could have this cloud hanging over my head for the next six months. There is only one way to be positive a lump is benign, and that is from the pathology when it is removed after surgery.  The first step, though, would be a biopsy.  Could you get a recommendation for a breast specialist from your GP?  That is the route I would take if I were in your shoes.  The statistics say that 80% of lumps are B9, so waiting is a choice you may be comfortable with.  But for your peace of mind, I would push for further testing.  I am very sorry for the loss of your dear friend. May she rest in a peaceful place where there is no BC. (((Hugs))) Diane

Posts.Content: DC197 wrote: I went to my primary care doctor today for a routine visit.  He said all my blood work, blood pressure, etc were fine and then proceeded to do a breast exam.  Lo and behold, he said he felt a lump in the same area as the original lump in 2010.  I was surprisingly calm, thinking that he must be wrong.  He put my finger where he felt it, and to tell the truth, I wasn't sure I felt anything. My surgery in 2010 was a partial mx, and there isn't a lot of tissue left, so when I press I think I'm feeling my chest wall. Anyway, next Tues. I'll be going for my Zometa infusion and seeing the NP. Every 2 months I either see my onc or her NP (they rotate) so I will have her check it.  My mammogram in Dec was fine, but of course that means nothing.  I'm trying to stay calm and not get ahead of myself, but my boat in that river in Egypt is predicting a storm brewing. Diane The Lord is my light and my salvation. Whom, then, should I fear? Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2013 10:18PM DC197 wrote: Hi belle, I'm sorry that you are dealing with this issue, but any new lump should be investigated and you did the right thing by having it checked.  The doctor at the imaging center doesn't feel that it is of major concern, and many times the doctors have enough experience to tell you their opinion.  However, no one can be absolutely sure if it is something benign or cancerous without a biopsy.  That being said, 80% of biopsies are B9, so the odds are definitely in your favor. You are not being paranoid, you are being reasonable.  Talk with your doctor, and get a referral for a biopsy.  It is well worth the cost for your piece of mind.  Good luck and come back to the boards to let us know how you are doing. Diane

Posts.Title: "deja vu all over again"? DC197 AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2013 03:49PM DC197 wrote: Here's my update: The NP at my onc office did a thorough exam and did not feel anything in my breast.  So she called my onc who said to order an ultrasound just to confirm that nothing was there.  The imaging center where I go would not do an u/s without first doing a mammo, so I agreed to it.  After being tortured by 7 views, 4 regular and 3 magnified, I sat and waited for a dr to review them.  All looked fine, so then had the u/s. I thought, fine, I'll be out of here with no problem.  The tech said the dr. would be in to review the findings. When she came in, she said the mammos are in black and white, while the u/s shows "shades of gray".  Who knew?  Anyway, the area behind the nipple looked different than it had on the previous u/s, which was before the surgery in 2010.  So now I am scheduled for a FN biopsy for a week from Friday.  I hope this all turns out to be for nothing, but if it is, I'm not gonna be happy that my primary dr put me through all this. Diane

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2012 12:46AM DC197 wrote: saylornagai, Sometimes we forget that the "newbies" as we call someone new to these boards, are not familiar with some of our terms.  B9 is a shortcut for "benign" meaning not cancerous.  Try not to read anything into the faces of the techs.  No one knows if a lump is malignant (cancerous) or benign until it's been biopsied and the pathology results come back from the lab.  Lumps can be a number of things and 80% of them are not cancer.  The waiting is the hardest part of all this, but I'm hoping that you will get an answer soon and that it will be B9! (((Hugs))) Diane

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2015 05:12PM DC197 wrote: I had a mild case of shingles while in my 40's. The rash healed, but the pain continued for a long time. When I turned 60, (before BC), I asked my PCP if I should get the shingles vaccine. He said there were two rules of thinking on that ... that my first case of shingles would be preventative or that it would not. I opted to get the vaccine because I have witnessed many severe cases of shingles in older family members and friends. Sometimes it comes back with a vengeance! I have seen 2 cases of shingles on the scalp which spread to the area near the eye. I was lucky enough to get vaccinated before my BC diagnosis, but everyone should ask their onc if it is advisable for them to get it. By the way, I also get a flu shot every year with no side effects (and no flu!)

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2013 08:33PM DC197 wrote: The Women's Health and Cancer Rights Act (WHCRA) was signed into law in 1998.  It requires health insurance companies to provide coverage of "(1) all stages of reconstruction of the breast on which the mastectomy has been preformed; (2) surgery and reconstruction of the other breast to produce a symmetrical appearance; and (3) prosetheses and physical complications of mastectomy, including lymphedemas. Requires annual written notice of the availability of such benefits." (quoted from the actual text of the WHCRA)
Posts.Title: Stage and grade of cancer determined AFTER surgery. What!?! InTheWind InTheWind

Posts.Content: DC197 wrote: Today is my second anniversary of being diagnosed with cancer.  When I was first diagnosed, I was told the lump was small, and there was no swelling in my lymph nodes, so I was probably stage 1 or 2.  But the BS wanted to be sure what he was dealing with, so I was sent for a breast MRI ... no problem, all was clear. I thought it would be smooth sailing.  Imagine my shock when the BS called and said that the lump was a little bigger than he had thought, and cancer was in 12/25 nodes.  When I met with the MO, she said my treatment would be aggressive, but first she arranged for me to have an echo, bone scan, and Ct scan. Ok, I thought, I'd better prepare myself for what lies ahead.  So when I found BCO, I read all the things that I should buy in preparation for chemo.  And then I shopped for a wig.  The MO called and said there were conflicting findings on the 2 scans, so she ordered an MRI, and set up a follow-up appt with her to receive my results.  By this time, it was the week after Christmas, so I had already asked that chemo treatments not start until that following Mon.  When I met with the MO on the Fri. before, she told me a met had been found on my spine, and that I would not be receiving chemo afterall. So, instead, I was given a script for anastrozole, and an appt for a Zometa infusion.  So, here I am today, feeling totally blessed that I have had 2 years pain-free, with very little side effects (only minor aches and hot flashes), and almost in denial that I am stage IV. Of course, I am never completely in denial, because it's a reality. I count every day as a blessing, trying not to squander this precious thing called LIFE! I also feel blessed that I can come to these boards and read the wisdom of so many sisters that have traveled this road.  At some point, far in the future, I hope, if the AIs aren't working and there is progression, I know I can come here and there will be someone to help me through it. God bless you all! Diane The Lord is my light and my salvation. Whom, then, should I fear? Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2013 09:54PM DC197 wrote: Virginia, I cannot answer most of your questions, but I know you must be staring at the computer waiting for a reply.  What I can tell you is this; there are many things that grow in a breast that are not cancer, so take a slow, deep breath and do not get ahead of yourself.  The saying here goes, it's not cancer until they say it's cancer.  As for pain, some women feel pain, some do not (I didn't).  And because you're pre-menopausal, it very likely something other than cancer if it fluctuates with your period.  The only advice I would give you is to have it checked out by a doctor for your peace of mind.  If, for some reason, cancer is found, don't panic.  There are a lot of treatments to consider, and other women will come along to answer some of your questions and tell you of their experience.  I truly hope that everything will turn out benign for you. (((hugs))) Diane

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2015 09:21AM DC197 wrote: My story is a little different. I injured my right pelvic area while washing a window and slipped. An MRI showed a fracture which is still painful after 3 months. By coincidence, the MRI showed mets in my left pelvis and left femur where I was not having any pain. The mets in the femur have eaten away 80% of the bone in one area and I am scheduled for surgery in 4 days. A rod will be put in my femur to stabilize it and then I will have radiation. And I agree, the pain is much worse at night and makes it difficult to sleep.

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2013 06:55PM DC197 wrote: Hi Cheer 2, Radiologists assign breast density into 4 categories: 1 Fatty 2 Scattered fibroglandular densities (average densities) 3 Heterogeneous Dense 4 Extremely Dense Hooray, you're normal!

Posts.Content: DC197 wrote: It's after midnight on the East coast, which means that it's been 6 years since I was first diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer right out of the gate. I had a small tumor in my right breast which had spread to my lymph nodes and to one small spot on my spine. The surgeon recommended a partial mastectomy, removal of all axillary nodes, followed by radiation to my chest and spine. Anastrozole worked for me for 5 years before progression. Since then, I've had a rod placement in my left femur and am taking Ibrance with letrozole. I am grateful to be living in this day and age where there are many treatments available, but we need a cure! Diane The Lord is my light and my salvation. Whom, then, should I fear? Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2012 12:48AM DC197 wrote: I don't think you have cause to worry if you are 2 months beyond your annual, unless you have symptoms which concern you.  You have probably been examined on both breasts over the course of treatment, plus you have been on chemo which is systemic.  If there were any microscopic cells in the right breast, the chemo may have worked on them as well.  I am not a doctor, of course, this is only my opinion.   (((Hugs))) Diane

Everyone's thinking is different, I guess. I sometimes wonder, too, why I should go through the pain of mammograms since they really don't pick up things well, especially in dense breasts, as mine are.  I'll try to remember to ask that next time. Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2013 11:39PM DC197 wrote: Cheer, It's not about the size of your breasts, it's about what your breast tissue is made up of.  So your breast is made up of less fatty tissue and more gland tissue.  Cancer is harder to detect on mammograms when the breast tissue is very dense.

Posts.Title: Update on Raro raro

Posts.Content: DC197 wrote: A couple of weeks ago I was at my primary dr's office, and he did a breast exam on me.  He said he felt a lump in my r/b (the one that had cancer).  I didn't feel anything in that area, but I was going in for my Zometa infusion the following week, so I had the NP from the onc's office do an exam.  She examined me thoroughly and didn't feel anything but scar tissue.  She called my onc who said to schedule a u/s. The imaging center wouldn't do a u/s without first doing a mammo, so I had both done. After checking the  7 views of the mammo and not seeing anything, I went for the u/s.  I figured I was good to go, until the doctor came in and said there were shading differences behind my nipple which caused concern. I am now scheduled for a biopsy on Fri.  Does anyone here have any thoughts on what this could mean since there isn't an actual lump?  I know the biopsy will determine whether it's cancer, but I am confused as to how this could appear in almost the exact area.  Is it possibly DCIS?  Any thoughts would be helpful. Diane The Lord is my light and my salvation. Whom, then, should I fear? Hormonal Therapy 9/19/2010 Arimidex (anastrozole) Dx 9/20/2010, IDC, Right, 2cm, Stage IV, metastasized to bone/liver, Grade 2, 12/25 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 11/14/2010 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Underarm/Axillary Surgery 11/3/2015 Hormonal Therapy 1/14/2016 Femara (letrozole) Targeted Therapy 1/14/2016 Ibrance (palbociclib) Radiation Therapy Whole-breast: Breast, Lymph nodes, Bone Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: new lump, maybe? kebab steelrose

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2012 05:17PM DC197 wrote: @ BlondeBunni ... You are taking the right steps to find out exactly what these lumps are.  I can tell you not to worry, but that would be foolish because we all worry when we first feel something that shouldn't be there. The pathology after your biopsy will tell you for certain whether or not it's bc, but 80% are b9, so the odds are in your favor, especially given your age. Relax, and keep breathing.  Do not trust Dr. Google, he'll only frighten you more. I will keep you in my thoughts and prayers, as I do all my sisters on this board. @ Ange-2012 ... I know the terror a 25 year old can feel about anything. I was 25 once (a long, long time ago).  Most of us on this board do not have a medical degree, but even if we did, we wouldn't be able to diagnose you via the internet.  If you are "sooo concerned" as you say, the only way to calm those fears is to take action.  Again, 80% of lumps are b9, so make an appt. with your doctor.  You don't have to be brave, you just have to show up.  Best of luck to you, and come back and report to us after you see the dr. (((Hugs))) to both! Diane

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2013 11:44PM DC197 wrote: This discussion is particularly interesting (and somewhat scary) to me at this time.  I had what the surgeon referred to as a partial mastectomy and complete axilary node dissection in Nov. 2010.  The following month, after having a ct, bone scan, and MRI in preparation for chemo, a single lesion was found on my spine. Fast forward to a week ago, when I had a mammo and u/s on the same breast.  Something suspicious showed up on the u/s and I am scheduled for a biopsy on Fri.  Had I know all of this back in 2010, I would have had a bmx, but unfortunately there's no going back. Diane

Posts.Title: Newbie with mets to bones and liver. in_cognito RavenAngel888

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2014 01:44AM DC197 wrote: Divine, your words are so true!  I, too, did everything the books say to do .. yearly mammogram, clinical breast exams, breast self-exams, and still dx as stage IV out of the gate.  In fact, I had an exam by my gyn less than a month before the mammogram found something needing further investigation.  I had the U/S and core biopsy, met with the surgeon who examined my underarm, and assured me that there was no node involvement.  (I hate being given false information when they really don't know).  Imagine my shock after surgery to discover that 12/25 nodes were positive and there was a met in my spine.   Until it happened to me, I always believed that breast cancer was the "easy" cancer.  Yep, if it's caught early, a little treatment and you're good to go.  No one ever told the truth about bc!!!  And their still hiding the facts under a bushel basket.  But, I'm preaching to the choir here, you all know the truth.  It's time for the world to hear us, and forget the pretty pink disease.  I wish Joan Lunden the best, but I cringed when she described herself as a warrior.

I am by no means an expert, but in answer to you question, I would schedule an appt. with a breast specialist.  Regardless of the findings of the biopsy, whether it is benign or not, I would think it prudent to have it removed, due to your family history. Good luck to you and come back here to let us know how you are doing.  (((Hugs))) Diane

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2012 05:16PM DC197 wrote: @Sara  ... I am so sorry that you got that diagnosis, but the doctor had no compassion to tell you that in those terms.  No one has an expiration date stamped on them.  So far, they haven't found a cure for us stage IVs, but there is always hope that research will find one soon.  As has been said by others, there are many treatments that can keep us going for years.  A "sister" on these boards recently passed after living for 14 years with stage IV. Do not give up hope! Your children only need to know that you will be taking some medicines to help you control your illness.  I would not mention anything beyond that, because they won't want to let you out of their sight for fear that you won't return. Just try to live your life as normally as possible and enjoy the beauty of each day.  Worrying won't change the diagnosis .. it will only add stress to your life. Check out the stage IV forum and you will get a lot of helpful information from the beautiful and knowledgeable ladies there.  You will hear how many have been surviving despite progression, cheer when there is regression, and sometimes get a laugh or two. I wish you many happy, enjoyable days and years on your journey. (((Hugs))) Diane

Posts.Title: In my pocket Maureen813 Maureen813

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2012 03:42AM - edited Jul 26, 2012 03:51AM by DC197 Hi Candy, I'm sorry that you are worried about this lump.  First of all, be assured that 80% of all lumps are benign, and given your age that is probably the case.  But, you did the right thing by having it checked out.  There are many changes in breast tissue, especially during the menstrual cycle, and when you mention it getting larger and then smaller, that may be the reason.  Breast cancer does not get smaller, as far as I know.  Can you move the lump around in your breast?  If so, it can be a fibroadenoma which is more common in younger females. If you decide to follow up with a biopsy, it really isn't very risky.  They numb the area and take a sample with a needle.  You don't feel anything except the initial prick when they numb it.  Good luck to you and let us know the outcome. (((Hugs))) Diane

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2015 02:48PM DC197 wrote: RaiderGirl, What you posted is the reality of a breast cancer dx. However, on a Just Diagnosed thread, when all the unknowns and fears are presented, it doesn't seem appropriate to add to those fears by listing all the negatives. It is true, there is no cure for BC, but many women who are dx at an early stage and get the appropriate treatment do go on to live a long and healthy life without recurrence. My focus is to give hope and advice to help those newly dx to get through treatment. As time goes on, and they are a little more comfortable in this journey, they will understand the realities that many of us face. And, I am in agreement that the statement, "One of the best cancers to get" is offensive to those of us dealing with it. I wish Shirlann a long and happy life and remission and hope that she will never be in position to regret those words. ~~Diane

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2013 04:24PM DC197 wrote: Gosh, I'm so sorry about all the stress this is causing you.  The pain/discomfort that you are feeling does not necessarily mean cancer.  We all tend to lump everything we're feeling into one big catagory, but the pain may be unrelated to the breast issue. One thing about cancer, though, is that not much changes over the course of a few months.  Since the doctor thinks it may be related to weaning, it may be ok to wait a few months and see if it resolves itself. With all the other stress in you life right now, relax and enjoy your vacation.  The statistics show that 80-85% of all biopsies are B9, so the odds are in your favor anyway. (((hugs))) Diane

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2012 01:08PM DC197 wrote: Hi Kpanna, I'm sorry that you are having to deal with this.  As Marie said, take some deep breaths and calm yourself a little. I know that's almost impossible, but don't let your mind jump too far ahead.  The saying here goes "You don't have cancer until they say you have cancer", and worrying about it won't change anything.  If it does turn out to be malignant (and I truly hope it does not) , it would have been growing for many years before becoming big enough to be discovered.  So, waiting a few more weeks will not change anything. If they suggest a biopsy, I would definately go for it.  The pathology from the biopsy will tell you if it is malignant or benign. (((hugs))) Diane

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2013 08:37PM DC197 wrote: Hi tkgmd, Radiologist assign breast density into 4 categories: 1 Fatty 2 Scattered fibroglandular densities (average densities) 3 Heterogeneous Dense 4 Extremely Dense Cancer is harder to detect in dense breasts.  You will probably be sent for an ultrasound scan.  I hope you have a good outcome. Diane

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2012 11:11PM DC197 wrote: @PKnudsen Mitotic rate describes how quickly the cancer cells are multiplying or dividing using a 1 to 3 scale, with 1 being the slowest, 3 the most rapid.  I don't know how the numbers >16/10 correspond to that scale. Tubule formation score of 1 means 75% of cells are in tubule formation (better), a score of 3 is used when less than 10% of cells are in tubule formation (worse). These two scores, plus the nuclear grade are combined to give the histological grade, either grade 1, 2, or 3. I'm so sorry that you have received this diagnosis, but once you have a treatment plan, you'll be on your way to good health again.  The ladies on this board have a wealth of information, so come back often and someone will be here that has walked the path before you. (((hugs))) Diane

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2013 11:44PM DC197 wrote: Hi partlycloudy, All of us that come to these boards can relate to the panic and fear when we don't yet have a diagnosis for a lump or pain in the breast.  I know how aggravating the wait can be, too.  But, if you can, just take a long, deep breath, blow it out until all the air is out of your lungs and diaphram ... (rinse and repeat lol). It does help to slow your heartbeat and calm your nerves.  I don't know if you are a religious person, but someone once told me that if you have trouble getting to sleep when your head is fillled with all the "what ifs", the advice was to "Give your troubles to God, he'll be up all night anyway".  I hope this helps. (((hugs))) Diane

So, I let them enjoy themselves because you're only young once. We did finally get new interior doors for all the rooms and closets.  That was something that I wanted for a long time. Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2013 08:18AM DC197 wrote: Hi j1, I am so sorry that you have to be here, but glad that you have found these boards.  You can be free to unburden yourself here, and be assured that the women here completely understand. You will also learn a lot from those that have walked the path before you. I read your other post and saw that you just turned 34.  Happy Birthday, although I don't think you were expecting bc as a gift.  My dx 2 years ago was very much like yours, except that I am older ... actually old enough to be your mother!  My one bone met was to my spine, and radiation zapped that away. Mets to the bone are treated like a chronic condition, and many bone-metsters on these boards have lived many years.  We are all just hanging around until research comes up with a complete cure, so don't loose hope. You may want to check out the Stage IV board where you'll find a lot of support. (((hugs))) Diane

Posts.Title: out of options onedayatatime NickyJ

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2012 09:39PM DC197 wrote: Hi bennymuffins, I'm so sorry that you have received this dx.  Don't get ahead of yourself. Breathe deeply and take one step at a time. And please don't use Dr. Google to find information, he will only scare the hell out of you.  The women on this forum have been through this and will tell it like it is.   Whatever the pathology shows, you are treatable!  As you can see from my signature, I am stage IV and coming up on my 2 year cancerversary and still feel well.  No one has an expiration date stamped on them.  I hope yours has not spread beyond the lymph nodes (the lymph nodes were doing what they're supposed to do - keep the cancer cells in check).  But these days, breast cancer is treated more like a chronic disease.  We just live with it while the research continues to look for a cure. So, here your cancer sisters will hold your hand, give you hugs, comfort you on bad days, and celebrate with you on the good days.  Be kind to yourself ... I know the waiting is tough. (((Hugs))) Diane
Posts.Title: In shock bennymuffins websister

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2017 02:27AM DC197 wrote: Hi everyone, This is just a post to introduce myself, as it is quite late here in Western NY, and my grandchildren will be coming over tomorrow and I'll need to be awake. My name is Diane, and I was first dx with bc in Sept, 2010. I was originally thought to be early stage, but after surgery with lymph node dissection and an MRI which found a lesion on my spine, I became stage IV de novo. It's funny, 7 years ago I wouldn't even know these terms to describe my disease! So, after surgery and radiation, I took anastrozole and zometa for 5 years without much change to my quality of life. I always knew in my heart, though, that I never wanted to have chemo and go through the horrifying treatments that I personally saw many family members and friends go through. I know that I am a bit of an anomaly, and even my oncologist admits that he doesn't have any patients like me. In the Fall of 2015, I had a PETCT scan, and, although I wasn't having any pain, cancer had found it's way to many bones in my body and was making a meal of those bones. The biggest concern was the femur in my left leg, so I had the surgery to insert a rod in that leg. My onc advised that my meds had to change, and prescribed Ibrance and letrozole. The Ibrance was at the highest dosage, and I experienced almost all the side effects listed. I was ready to give up entirely, but he changed to a lower dosage that I was able to tolerate. That worked (I thought) for about 14 months when I had the last PET/CT. My intuition told me that something was amiss, but I wasn't prepared when he told me that it was now in my liver. That's it for tonight ... gotta get some sleep ... I've enjoyed reading all your posts and "meeting" all of you. Diane
Posts.Title: Completely Scary Topic: How Do We Die? blainejennifer magdalene51

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2012 04:27AM DC197 wrote: Mammograms are seldom done on young women because they have dense breasts and they are not able to see anything.  More likely, the doctor would order an ultrasound. Diane
Posts.Title: Nipple pain, indentation, and lump - please help and read joanne725 joanne725

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2012 11:56PM DC197 wrote: Hi Mad, I was diagnosed as stage IV from the get-go in Sept. 2010, with one lesion on my spine.  I had radiation to my breast, axilla, and spine an have been taking the generic of Arimidex every day and Zometa infusions every two months.  Except for minor aches, it has been working well for me and I am stable and hope to continue to be for a long time. Best of luck to you with this treatment.
Posts.Title: Arimidex success rate MadhuriUpadhyay SyrMom

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2012 01:53AM DC197 wrote: Trina, My condolences on the loss of your brother.  That alone is a lot to deal with at your young age.  The loss of your job was just added stress to what you were already going through, but to be hit with a dx of breast cancer seems so horribly unfair.  I know you must have a lot of fear at this point, but don't jump too far ahead until you know exactly what you are dealing with. Once you have the pathology report, your oncologist will formulate a treatment plan for you.  Please come back here often with any questions you may have.  The women on this board are very compassionate and knowledgeable and will guide you along the way.  Here you can express your true feelings, and we can empathize because we have been there.  Let us know how you are doing ... we care! (((Hugs))) Diane
Posts.Title: just diagnosed Trina25 BlondeBunni

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2013 03:07PM DC197 wrote: Judie, It's heartbreaking to hear that you are having so much pain.  I hope the rads get it under control soon.  Sending positive energy and gentle (((hugs))). Diane
Posts.Title: Delay in Chemo and 20 Rads sessions justjudie pajim

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2012 04:24AM DC197 wrote: Joanne, I'm sorry that you're in pain and so confused and frightened.  I really don't have any answers for you, but perhaps one of the women who might have similar symptoms may post here.  I'm glad that you have made a doctor's appointment, but maybe if you called and explained your pain, the doctor might be able to see you sooner.  Waiting for answers is the hardest part, so I would try to be seen by the doctor as soon as possible to calm your fears. I hope you will have a good outcome, and please let us know how you are doing. (((Hugs))) Diane
